article.text: In Singapore, the Redmi 7 is priced at S$179 for the version with 16GB ROM and 2GB RAM, as well as S$199 for 32GB ROM and 3GB RAM. S$20 more for double the storage is definitely the version I recommend. These days, 16GB is not enough. (Trust me, I used the 16GB Redmi 5 for a year.)

As a Redmi 5 user, last year’s Redmi 6 was a huge disappointment. Other than the camera on the rear, it was a step down from its predecessor in every way. It was much smaller, the speaker was shifted to the rear, plus its looked really cheap. I did not bother asking for a review unit.

Thankfully, Xiaomi realized that it was a bad idea and made Redmi 7 a much worthier successor to the Redmi 5. But the competition is now much stronger. Should you still go for the Redmi 7? How big of an improvement is it from the Redmi 5? Let’s find out.
Design – Stunning Looks, Not So Great Feel
Rear & Sides

Ditching the metal-looking plastic design on the Redmi 6, the Redmi 7 has a… is that a glass body? Nope. Like the Honor 10 Lite I reviewed earlier, Redmi 7’s plastic body looks like glass and is gorgeous. It comes in Comet Blue and Black in Singapore, the latter featured in this review.
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg1.jpg?alt=media&token=df33d6f8-38fb-412f-b03a-18c99f868b0c

Being plastic though, the rear of the device is easily scratched and this scratches are very clear if you get the black version. I highly recommend you use the included clear jelly case. But if you do not like to put a case on your phone, then get the Comet Blue version.

Unlike the Honor 10 Lite though, the sides of Redmi 7 do not have the same glossy finish. Instead, Xiaomi opted for a matte frame which doesn’t look as sleek, but it looks arguably better looking than the Redmi 5 and a lot better than the Redmi 6. But holding the device is another story.
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg2.jpg?alt=media&token=4237fc48-f1cf-4887-9c24-55d48c94c9cd

At the part where the plastic rear and frame meet, the frame overlaps the rear panel with a noticeable gap in between. Not only is it easy for dirt to get stuck in between, you can feel the sharp edge of the frame when gripping the device. Not cool. The fingerprint scanner cutout is also a bit sharp.
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg3.jpg?alt=media&token=529b9fcf-c2a9-48fb-8a7e-04c09d70b23a

There is a dual camera setup on the rear. And like the Redmi Note 7, Redmi 7 comes with the new “Redmi by Xiaomi” branding. As the back panel is plastic, Xiaomi was able to curve it to provide a better grip. On top, we have an IR blaster, a headphone jack and a microphone hole.
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg4.jpg?alt=media&token=a4172707-026e-461f-97ad-5110f8bb6a53
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg5.jpg?alt=media&token=e9816041-63f8-42f1-904f-cbf018a74b45

Below is a micro USB port between 2 grills. Yep, unlike the Redmi Note 7, this one still uses micro USB. Also, as usual, only the right grill houses a speaker. To the right, we have a SIM tray with two nano SIM slots, plus a dedicated microSD card slot. Sweet!
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg6.jpg?alt=media&token=a54705bf-29e5-4353-a886-696bb70761df
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg7.jpg?alt=media&token=7c7e6d4b-16aa-4ac0-9f4e-e385dabe6fe7
Front & Display

Now, to the front. We have a 6.26″ HD+ IPS LCD display, with a 19:9 aspect ratio. That is almost as big as the Redmi Note 7’s 6.3″ display. Has the note lost its meaning? Bezels are huge, but the notch is tiny, housing only a single camera. We have a speaker grill hidden at the edge on top.
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg8.jpg?alt=media&token=a3809dbf-b2a0-48e1-8376-5e45d4402012
The display is plenty bright, but for some reason, it doesn’t feel as nice of a display as the Redmi Note 7’s. Probably due to that screen bleeding below, which is very obvious.

Overall, the Redmi 7 looks a lot like the Redmi Note 7, including the size; that is to say, very attractive. But the moment you hold it, you can tell that Redmi Note 7 is the superior device. But starting at only S$179, you are paying quite a bit less with the Redmi 7, so this is expected.
Performance – Powerful Enough for PUBG Mobile?
Powering the Redmi 7 is the Snapdragon 632 processor, with 2/3GB RAM. Hopefully you bought the 3GB RAM version as 2GB is just barely enough to run MIUI and the basic processes smoothly.

So how does the Redmi 7 perform? With the 3GB RAM version, PUBG Mobile was playable on the lowest graphics settings, but it wasn’t the smoothest experience. Meanwhile, Asphalt 9 ran without stutter on default graphics, but there were noticeable frame drops on high quality graphics.
In AnTuTu, Redmi 7 scored 103244, over 40% higher than the Redmi 5. We also saw huge improvements in Geekbench 4, with the Redmi 7 scoring 1236 and 4282 for single and multi-core respectively.
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg9.jpg?alt=media&token=65b1ca46-2e9e-454f-ba75-b39f273dd1c4
Rear Cameras – Good, But Don’t Get Your Expectations Too High

On the rear of the Redmi 7 is a dual camera setup. The main camera is a 12MP sensor with 1.25μm pixels and f/2.2 aperture. Sound familiar? On paper, this is identical to the one on the Redmi 5. Could they be the same? The secondary 2MP camera is only for depth sensing.

Photos turn out good in the day, but colors are a little too saturated, and maybe even too artificial. At night, photos turn out usable with well controlled noise, though they can be a little soft and areas with lights are blown out. Xiaomi did not include any night mode in the Redmi 7’s camera app.
Edge detection for portrait shots is very meh. Overall, this dual camera setup isn’t significantly better than the Redmi 5’s single camera, so I wouldn’t consider this an upgrade.
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg19.jpg?alt=media&token=aa8e3e12-027d-49be-87f5-913713c23936
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg20.jpg?alt=media&token=bdf1a10b-c5ca-4ca1-bd58-a93a1f044bde
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg21.jpg?alt=media&token=5bf3ecdb-6adc-44e0-b731-c6a2769f3677

The rear cameras on Redmi 7 can record videos up to 1080p 60fps. Dynamic rage isn’t very good, but that is to be expected from a phone this price. Its biggest weakness though, is the lack of stabilization.
https://www.youtube.com/embed/jtGGTkGZQXM
Selfie Camera – Not Bad for a Budget Device
Selfies taken with the Redmi 7’s 8MP front-facing camera has great colors and dynamic range is surprisingly acceptable. Selfies at night is also not too bad, as long as there is adequate lighting.
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg22.jpg?alt=media&token=a6c1d69b-80aa-4834-8eb0-fb5344f8c15b
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg23.jpg?alt=media&token=bf83096c-2174-472d-9df7-053f74708870
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg24.jpg?alt=media&token=9db07d51-893d-4c82-b740-ea426b05685e
Battery Life – More Than Enough to Get You Through a Day

With a 4000mAh battery and a not very power-hungry processor, you can expect great battery life on the Redmi 7. On moderate to intensive usage, I was able to drain the Redmi 7 to 32% battery by 9PM, with a screen-on time of 4h 16min. This is comparable to the battery life of its predecessor.
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg25.jpg?alt=media&token=46c87241-0966-4077-b7c4-369ba6d88173
Software – Just MIUI

Redmi 7 runs MIUI 10.2 on top of Android Pie out of the box. This is the ad-filled version of MIUI and if you have used any Xiaomi device in the past, this should be very familiar to you. I do love the new wallpapers Xiaomi included with the Redmi 7, which are vibrant and fun.
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/logicui-9667a.appspot.com/o/reviews%2Fredmi-7-review%2Fimg26.jpg?alt=media&token=ddd9b4eb-0264-4ffe-8314-1aa180e700ea
Future Improvements
Overall, I am pleased with the Redmi 7, but there are many areas that Xiaomi can still improve on.

Firstly, build quality. Yes, the Redmi 7 looks amazing for a S$200 device. But small things like the gap between the frame and rear panel can really degrade the experience. I don’t mind something less fanciful like the POCO F1, but the craftsmanship must be there.

Next, I hope Xiaomi will abandon the 16GB version and make 32GB the base storage option. Honestly, 16GB is barely enough for anything these days; a couple of songs, some important but small apps and you have already run out of space. Same for the RAM. No more 2GB please.

Lastly, with USB Type-C already making its way to the Redmi Note 7, I am sure that Xiaomi can add that to next year’s non-note Redmi device. These days, people rarely carry a micro USB cable around any more so it is about time we phase out the micro USB port.
